report_title: Electrical Equipment Manufacturing in the US
executive_summary: Electrical equipment manufacturers have endured moderate volatility in recent years. During the initial stages of the pandemic, changes in demand from the industrial sector, one of the largest downstream users of electrical equipment, negatively impacted equipment manufacturers. Significant supply chain disruptions, social distancing requirements and weaker demand for manufactured products led to revenue losses, a trend enhanced by instability in the nonresidential construction sector. However, the ongoing economic recovery has enabled demand for manufactured goods to bounce back, while historically high corporate profit has boosted demand for construction projects. As a result, revenue has grown at an estimated CAGR of 2.7% to $57.1 billion through the current period, including a 0.4% gain in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: A Strengthening Industrial Sector Drives Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: New electrical equipment sales heavily correlate to the industrial sector's performance. Other manufacturing, mining, utilities and gas industries are major buyers of electrical equipment. In particular, these buyers often create contracts with the industry for expensive, custom-built electrical systems to handle complex assembly lines, power generation and other energy-intensive tasks.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: INPUT PRICE VOLATILITY IMPACTS THE INDUSTRY'S PERFORMANCE
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Raw and semifinished material prices have endured significant volatility recently, particularly steel, copper and aluminum. Climbing semiconductor and electronic component prices have also faced price increases amid heightened demand for manufactured products, pressuring purchasing expenses for most manufacturers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: ELEVATED INTEREST RATES PLACE DOWNWARD PRESSURE ON SALES
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Like industrial markets, the construction sector is one of the largest downstream buyers of electrical equipment. Contractors install electrical equipment across all residential, nonresidential, industrial and utility construction projects.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Household Electrical Demand Provides a Solid Baseline
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Households and businesses need electricity for most daily tasks, like lighting homes and accessing the internet. Consumer electrical demand often exhibits seasonal cyclicality, with higher demand in the summer months. Manufacturers often rely on weather forecasts to prepare for elevated demand during especially hot summers or other one-off weather phenomenon.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Stabilizing Input Prices Will Support Manufacturers' Performance
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Input prices, like steel, copper and electronic components, will stabilize as economic conditions improve. Lower purchase costs often contribute to weaker revenue, as manufacturers charge lower prices for electrical equipment. However, companies may be able to pass cost savings onto buyers, stimulating greater demand.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Government Spending Will Support Electrical Equipment Manufacturers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA) will continue to create funding opportunities for electricity transmission and utility companies, supporting demand for domestic electrical equipment manufacturers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: VOLATILE OPERATING EXPENSES IMPACT EQUIPMENT PRODUCERS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Concerns regarding climate change and an emphasis on ESG-related products will encourage major companies to increase investment in more efficient technologies like copper-wired electric motors and flexible transformers. Copper carries an electric current more effectively than aluminum but costs significantly more.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: MANUFACTURERS WILL FIND GROWTH OPPORTUNITIES ABROAD
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The expected depreciation of the US dollar will cause import penetration to weaken and exports to grow as a share of revenue. A weaker dollar makes domestically produced equipment more competitive in the global market as it becomes comparatively more affordable while making imports comparatively more expensive, pushing some buyers to buy domestic equipment.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures power, distribution and specialty transformers; electric motors, generators and motor-generator sets, switchgear and switchboard apparatus, relays and industrial controls. Electrical equipment manufacturers sell their products to other manufacturing industries, wholesalers and the construction sector.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: high - steady

key_trends: Manufacturers have increasingly moved overseas to combat rising costs. Import penetration remains a key issue for domestic electrical equipment manufacturers with imported equipment accounting for more than half of domestic demand.
Companies often specialize in specific niches and markets. Large competitors often target niche equipment manufacturers to expand into new regions and generate more robust market share.

Climbing interest rates have reduced demand from the construction sector, a significant buyer of electrical equipment. Companies will rely on sustained government funding to support utility construction buyers.

Many manufacturers are increasing investment in renewables to improve efficiency and expand market reach. Adopting sustainable energy requires companies to upgrade their electrical equipment, driving sales.
The industrial sector's recovery created numerous growth opportunities for electrical equipment manufacturers.
Leading manufacturers often operate through multiple peripheral industries, like power conversion equipment manufacturing.
Manufacturers must respond to changing environmental regulations.
Manufacturers will benefit from the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA) and funding to enhance the nation's power grid.
Companies rely on skilled labor to design and manufacture products.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Many producers continue to rely on wholesalers to distribute their products. Wholesalers act as an intermediary by purchasing electrical equipment in bulk from manufacturers and selling it to downstream buyers.

Equipment manufacturers commonly sell to industrial manufacturing. While most manufacturers purchase electrical equipment in bulk through wholesalers, these buyers have leveraged online ordering systems to bypass distributors to access products without wholesale markup.

The construction market comprises building contractors, heavy construction companies and businesses. Retailers include stores selling electrical equipment directly to end users, including individuals and small businesses.

Businesses often purchase electrical equipment for internal operations rather than resale or distribution to other buyers. This segment relies on robust corporate profit and positive business sentiment.

products_and_services.product_description: Relays and Industrial Controls: key points related to relays and industrial controls.
Switchgear and Switchboards: key points related to switchgear and switchboards.
Motors and Generator Manufacturing: key points related to motors and generator manufacturing.
Transformers: key points related to transformers.

tier_1_suppliers: Tool & Hardware Wholesaling in the US
Industrial Machinery & Equipment Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Screw, Nut & Bolt Manufacturing in the US
Copper Rolling, Drawing & Extruding in the US
tier_1_buyers: Electrical Equipment Wholesaling in the US
Electronic Part & Equipment Wholesaling in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The industrial production index measures the output of the manufacturing, mining and utility sectors. The industrial sector has the highest energy consumption rate, so demand for electrical equipment largely follows industrial production.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Tariffs Reduce China's Impact on Import Markets
international_trade_points.trade_description: The United States has imposed higher tariff rates on Chinese imports as part of the ongoing trade war, especially following intellectual property breaches in the technology sector. Chinese imports have plummeted through the current period, yet the country remains a leading factor in trade markets.

Offshoring practices are common among manufacturers to reap the benefits of operating in countries with lower operating costs, like Mexico and China. These foreign producers can offer competitive prices while maintaining a higher profit.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement Encourages Trade Activity Between Member Countries
international_trade_points.trade_description: Mexico and Canada are the two largest destinations for domestically produced electrical equipment. The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) facilitates trade between these countries through reduced applicable tariffs.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Domestic Manufacturers Offer High-Quality Electrical Equipment
international_trade_points.trade_description: Domestic electrical equipment manufacturers often differentiate with more expensive, higher-quality products. These products compete more directly with German, Canadian and Japanese products rather than generic Chinese and Mexican goods.

business_locations.location_description: Electrical equipment manufacturers in the Southeast leverage established trade routes through the Gulf of Mexico to trade with Mexico and South America. Having easy access to these major trade routes helps keep transportation costs lower. The region also has a high population, strengthening manufacturing, construction and consumer activity. This trend leads to more stable and predictable demand from the Southeast region. The Southeast also boasts a strong manufacturing workforce, supported by robust technical schools and training programs. This trend ensures that manufacturers have access to highly skilled labor.

Many large manufacturers are located in the Great Lakes region. As a major manufacturing hub, the region enables electrical equipment manufacturers to access key supply chain members, especially in the steel and auto manufacturing industries. Major companies benefit from proximity to buyers and suppliers in the Great Lakes. Similarly, these companies rely more on imports to Canada, especially through crucial trade routes like the Detroit-Windsor Tunnel. Proximity to raw material suppliers and key markets reduces transportation costs and streamlines production processes, giving manufacturers a logistical advantage.

Electrical equipment manufacturers rely on skilled labor and prefer to be near their buyers. California attracts many technology industries and skilled workers, so many companies form partnerships with California tech companies to improve products. The West also houses several major international ports, enabling manufacturers to trade with the Asia-Pacific nations. The West region is also home to a growing manufacturing center.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Manufacturers must adhere to EPA regulations regarding air, water and noise pollution. The EPA regulates electrical equipment manufacturers by forcing coal-powered electric plants to keep carbon emissions low. This also applies to fossil-fuel-powered utility boilers. These regulations are highly pertinent to the industry and its downstream manufacturing buyers. The EPA enforces multiple regulations, including the Clean Air Act, Clean Water Act and Resource Conservation and Recovery Act.

Manufacturers are governed by laws and regulations relating to workplace safety and worker health. The Occupational Safety and Health Act (OSHA) Covers several topics relating to worker safety, including break and meal times, noise levels and dust standards. Companies are also held accountable to various state OSHAs, which may vary from their federal counterpart.

The Energy Policy Act of 2005 empowers the Energy Department by permitting the Secretary to issue grants that motivate electrical equipment manufacturers to escalate the utilization of renewable resources such as geothermal, solar and wind for electricity generation. The Act also facilitates enhancing energy efficiency and the modernization of transmission infrastructure.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 seeks to upgrade the electric power grid. The act encourages the advancement of cyber security protections, the integration of new data systems and the adoption of innovative technologies such as electric vehicles. This legislative measure spearheads a critical industry transformation, resulting in significant changes within the electrical equipment manufacturing sector as more companies gear up to meet these increased cyber security and data requirements.

The National Electrical Code (NEC) is a set of safety standards for installing electrical wiring and equipment. Although the NEC is not federally enforced, many state and local governments. As a result, manufacturers must produce equipment that meets NEC standards. Failing to comply with these standards can impact producers' reputations and could result in legal consequences.

ISO 9001 is a globally recognized quality management system standard. For electrical equipment manufacturers, achieving ISO 9001 certification demonstrates a commitment to quality management principles, including customer focus, process improvement and regulatory compliance. It can improve operational efficiency and enhance customer satisfaction.

FCC regulations govern electromagnetic interference (EMI) to ensure that electrical equipment does not interfere with other electronic devices. Manufacturers must test products for compliance with EMI standards. Adhering to FCC regulations ensures smoother product launches and avoids legal penalties, ensuring a seamless user experience.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The electrical equipment manufacturing industry is mature.
The industry has a high and increasing level of globalization.

basis_points.basis_description: Import penetration remains a key issue for domestic electrical equipment manufacturers with imported equipment accounting for more than half of domestic demand.
Companies often specialize in specific niches and markets.
Large competitors often target niche equipment manufacturers to expand into new regions and generate more robust market share.

concentration_points.concentration_description: While many manufacturers operate smaller facilities with fewer than 50 employees, extensive barriers to entry, including capital requirements and economies of scale, enable large companies to dominate the market and span multiple lucrative niches.
The four largest electrical equipment manufacturers comprise more than 20.0% of revenue for electrical equipment manufacturers, with Eaton leading the charge.

The electrical equipment manufacturing process is complex and highly labor and capital-intensive. As a result, many companies lack the capacity to span multiple segments and specialize in specific products to maximize returns and develop strong reputations.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Manufacturers rely heavily on highly skilled workers to design new and produce existing equipment. Companies require advanced degrees, like electrical engineering, to build electric circuits in transformers, electric motors, switchgear and relays.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Manufacturers have increasingly used copper to improve connectivity. Companies have traditionally used aluminum for its cost-effectiveness, but many manufacturers have adopted higher-quality inputs to attract new customers and differentiate from foreign competitors. Manufacturers have also started using square wires instead of round wires because they produce stronger magnetic fields. By developing and adopting these new technologies, domestic producers can become more competitive against affordable imports.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Better Electric Motors Cut the Costs of Electrical Equipment Manufacturers
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Manufacturers have increasingly used copper to improve connectivity. Companies have traditionally used aluminum for its cost-effectiveness, but many manufacturers have adopted higher-quality inputs to attract new customers and differentiate from foreign competitors.

Buyers can move flexible transformers from one region to another. Power companies can move these transformers to cater to peak electricity demand in different regions, creating better value per unit. Power companies will store and purchase fewer transformers, leading to higher efficiency and lower long-term costs for downstream clients. These flexible transformers will garner higher prices.

volatility_points.volatility_title: High Interest Rates Disrupt Construction Markets
volatility_points.volatility_description: The construction sector is one of the industry's largest buyers since homes, apartment complexes and offices need electrical wiring, circuitry and other electrical equipment. Homeowners, contractors and repairmen frequently purchase power tools for internal improvements, too. However, skyrocketing inflation following the pandemic has forced multiple rounds of interest rate hikes. These higher borrowing costs negatively impacted housing starts, home improvement spending and nonresidential construction projects, especially in the manufacturing sector.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Consumer and Business Sentiment Dictate Major Fluctuations
volatility_points.volatility_description: Downstream manufacturers use energy generation and transmission equipment in common household products like appliances. However, changes in macroeconomic conditions, including falling consumer confidence and disposable income, have placed downward pressure on sales, contributing to revenue volatility. Electrical components are largely used across multiple manufacturing industries as a common input. Unfavorable economic conditions push consumers to postpone non-essential purchases, harming demand for manufactured products and causing revenue growth to slow down.

Electrical equipment is essential across a wide range of diverse industries, including manufacturing, power transmission and generation, construction and service-based industries. Electrical switchboards and transformers are used in nearly every residential and nonresidential building. Similarly, various electrical components are essential to functioning household appliances and motor vehicles. This market diversity gives companies extra flexibility if singular markets face downturns. For example, many companies have mitigated weak construction activity by growth in energy generation and utilities markets, given the push for green energy.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Better Electric Motors Cut the Costs of Electrical Equipment Manufacturers
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Manufacturers have increasingly used copper to improve connectivity. Companies have traditionally used aluminum for its cost-effectiveness, but many manufacturers have adopted higher-quality inputs to attract new customers and differentiate from foreign competitors.

Buyers can move flexible transformers from one region to another. Power companies can move these transformers to cater to peak electricity demand in different regions, creating better value per unit. Power companies will store and purchase fewer transformers, leading to higher efficiency and lower long-term costs for downstream clients. These flexible transformers will garner higher prices.

FAQs.question: What are ISO standards?
FAQs.answer: ISO 9001 is a globally recognized quality management system standard. For electrical equipment manufacturers, achieving ISO 9001 certification demonstrates a commitment to quality management principles, including customer focus, process improvement and regulatory compliance. It can improve operational efficiency and enhance customer satisfaction.

FAQs.question: What are FCC regulations?
FAQs.answer: FCC regulations govern electromagnetic interference (EMI) to ensure that electrical equipment does not interfere with other electronic devices. Manufacturers must test products for compliance with EMI standards. Adhering to FCC regulations ensures smoother product launches and avoids legal penalties, ensuring a seamless user experience.

FAQs.question: What assistance does the National Electrical Manufacturers Association (NEMA) provide?
FAQs.answer: NEMA was founded in 1926 and represents nearly 325 electrical equipment and medical imaging manufacturers. The organization writes standards that encourage manufacturers to comply with national and local standards, help management make business decisions and lobby for the interests of electrical equipment companies in Congress.

FAQs.question: How have rising imports impacted companies?
FAQs.answer: Rising imports have been an issue for operators and have caused companies to rethink operations. Consequently, companies must compete by increasing the quality of their products.

FAQs.question: Have export opportunities benefited companies?
FAQs.answer: Falling exports tied to poor industrial performance hurt many companies, but commodity price rebounds could help. Exports are also expected to rebound as the dollar's value falls relative to other currencies.

FAQs.question: Have companies explored acquisitions in locations with established infrastructure?
FAQs.answer: The largest few companies have bolstered themselves with acquisitions. This will lead to a moderate level of concentration.

FAQs.question: Are companies located near key distributors to reduce shipping costs?
FAQs.answer: Companies tend to locate near international shipping hubs, which cuts down on costs at both ends of the supply chain. This will also lead to other upstream and downstream industries located nearby.

FAQs.question: Have companies reduced wage costs through automation?
FAQs.answer: Automation and advanced manufacturing have been key objectives for the best-performing companies because they reduce wage costs, reduce human error and streamline processes. Companies have also invested heavily in offshoring operations.

FAQs.question: How do companies invest in technology for a competitive edge?
FAQs.answer: Companies invest in technology to meet downstream trends or risk falling behind. Additionally, companies dedicate significant revenue to research and development.

FAQs.question: How do companies stay ahead of regulations like energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: Companies use industry associations and focus on R&D in new technologies to help stay ahead. Companies also partner with governmental organizations to develop internal abilities further.

FAQs.question: Have regulatory expenses impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Regulations have caused more interest in efficiency, which supports more value-added products. Companies must also adhere to manufacturing protocols.

FAQs.question: How does a company's profit compare to competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit fluctuates according to general economic conditions, but companies that have improved are outpacing the competition. There has also been increased competition.

FAQs.question: How do companies compensate for seasonality of cashflow?
FAQs.answer: The connection to construction creates seasonality, but having diversified customers can alleviate this. Companies may also rely on different applications to diversify demand.
